description: Comprehensive assessment framework for evaluating applications across business value, technical health, cost, and modernization potential.

dimensions.name: 1. Business Criticality & Impact
dimensions.description: Evaluates the application's importance to business operations, revenue, and customer impact.

aspects.name: 1.1. Revenue Impact & Dependency
aspects.rationale: Applications that directly generate or support revenue are critical to business survival and growth.

questions.text: Does this application directly generate revenue (e.g., e-commerce platform, subscription service)?
questions.why: Direct revenue generation represents the highest level of business criticality, as application failure directly impacts the company's bottom line.

questions.text: What is the estimated financial impact per hour of application downtime?
questions.why: Quantifying downtime cost helps prioritize investments in reliability and disaster recovery based on actual business impact.

questions.text: How many critical business processes (order fulfillment, manufacturing, billing) would be disrupted by application failure?
questions.why: Understanding process dependencies reveals the application's role in core business operations and helps assess operational risk.

questions.text: What percentage of employees rely on this application to perform their primary job functions?
questions.why: Widespread user dependency indicates high organizational impact and potential productivity loss during outages.

questions.text: Does this application serve external customers or partners directly?
questions.why: Customer-facing applications have higher visibility and direct impact on customer satisfaction and brand reputation.

aspects.name: 1.2. Strategic Alignment & Value
aspects.rationale: Applications must align with and enable strategic business objectives to justify investment and maintenance.

questions.text: How directly does this application support achievement of key business strategy objectives?
questions.why: Strategic alignment ensures IT investments are focused on enabling business goals rather than maintaining legacy systems with diminishing returns.

questions.text: What unique business capabilities or competitive advantages does this application enable?
questions.why: Applications providing competitive differentiation warrant higher investment to maintain and enhance their strategic value.

questions.text: How would decommissioning this application impact business operations and strategic initiatives?
questions.why: Understanding the consequences of removal helps determine if an application is truly essential or a candidate for retirement.

questions.text: What is the business's appetite for investing in this application's evolution and modernization?
questions.why: Business sponsorship and willingness to invest are critical factors in determining the application's future and modernization priority.

questions.text: How does this application integrate with and support other critical business systems and processes?
questions.why: Integration points reveal dependencies and the application's role in broader business ecosystems, affecting change management complexity.

dimensions.name: 2. Technical Health & Obsolescence
dimensions.description: Assesses the application's technical condition, modernity, and freedom from operational debt.

aspects.name: 2.1. Technology Stack & Modernity
aspects.rationale: Current technologies reduce security risks, improve maintainability, and leverage modern capabilities.

questions.text: What is the support status of the application's core technologies (programming languages, frameworks, databases)?
questions.why: Unsupported or end-of-life technologies pose security risks, compliance issues, and increasing maintenance costs.

questions.text: How difficult is it to find developers with expertise in this application's technology stack?
questions.why: Scarce skills increase labor costs, extend hiring timelines, and create key-person dependency risks.

questions.text: Does the application architecture leverage modern patterns (microservices, cloud-native, API-first)?
questions.why: Modern architectures enable scalability, flexibility, and faster feature delivery compared to monolithic legacy designs.

questions.text: What is the level of technical debt in the codebase, and how does it impact development velocity?
questions.why: High technical debt slows development, increases bug rates, and makes the application increasingly expensive to maintain.

questions.text: How comprehensive and effective is the automated test suite covering the application?
questions.why: Quality test coverage enables safe refactoring, reduces regression risks, and supports continuous delivery practices.

aspects.name: 2.2. Operational Stability & Performance
aspects.rationale: Reliable performance and minimal disruptions are essential for user satisfaction and business continuity.

questions.text: What is the application's historical availability and mean time between failures (MTBF)?
questions.why: Availability metrics provide objective evidence of reliability and help identify applications requiring stability improvements.

questions.text: How does the application perform under peak load conditions, and what are its scalability limits?
questions.why: Performance under load determines the application's ability to support business growth and handle seasonal demand spikes.

questions.text: What is the mean time to recovery (MTTR) when incidents or outages occur?
questions.why: Fast recovery capabilities minimize business impact during failures and indicate operational maturity.

questions.text: How many high-severity production incidents has the application experienced in the past year?
questions.why: Incident frequency indicates stability problems and helps prioritize applications for reliability engineering.

questions.text: What monitoring, alerting, and diagnostic capabilities are in place for the application?
questions.why: Comprehensive observability enables proactive issue detection, faster troubleshooting, and better user experience management.

aspects.name: 2.3. Security & Compliance
aspects.rationale: Security vulnerabilities and compliance gaps create business risks that must be addressed.

questions.text: What critical or high-severity security vulnerabilities are currently open for this application?
questions.why: Unaddressed vulnerabilities represent immediate security risks that could lead to data breaches or system compromises.

questions.text: How does the application handle sensitive data, and what encryption and access controls are implemented?
questions.why: Proper data protection is essential for regulatory compliance and preventing unauthorized access to sensitive information.

questions.text: What compliance requirements (GDPR, HIPAA, PCI DSS) does the application need to meet, and how well does it comply?
questions.why: Compliance gaps can result in legal penalties, fines, and loss of business licenses or certifications.

questions.text: When was the last security penetration test or comprehensive security assessment performed?
questions.why: Regular security testing identifies vulnerabilities that automated scans might miss and validates the effectiveness of security controls.

questions.text: How are security updates and patches managed for the application and its dependencies?
questions.why: Timely patch management is critical for addressing known vulnerabilities and maintaining a secure application posture.

dimensions.name: 3. Total Cost of Ownership
dimensions.description: Evaluates all costs associated with maintaining and operating the application.

aspects.name: 3.1. Direct & Operational Costs
aspects.rationale: Understanding full costs reveals optimization opportunities and informs investment decisions.

questions.text: What are the annual licensing, subscription, and infrastructure costs for this application?
questions.why: Direct costs represent the most visible portion of TCO and are often the easiest to quantify and optimize.

questions.text: How many full-time equivalent (FTE) resources are dedicated to application support and maintenance?
questions.why: Labor costs typically represent the largest component of TCO and should be optimized through automation and efficiency improvements.

questions.text: What are the costs associated with unplanned downtime and emergency support incidents?
questions.why: Reactive support costs indicate stability problems and help justify investments in reliability improvements.

questions.text: What technical debt remediation and mandatory upgrade costs are anticipated over the next 3 years?
questions.why: Future mandatory investments must be factored into TCO calculations to avoid budget surprises and ensure long-term sustainability.

questions.text: How do this application's costs compare to industry benchmarks or alternative solutions?
questions.why: Benchmarking reveals cost optimization opportunities and helps determine if the application is economically efficient to maintain.

aspects.name: 3.2. Efficiency & Optimization Potential
aspects.rationale: Identifying efficiency opportunities can reduce costs and free up resources for strategic initiatives.

questions.text: What opportunities exist to optimize infrastructure costs through right-sizing or cloud migration?
questions.why: Infrastructure optimization often delivers quick cost savings with minimal application changes.

questions.text: How could automation reduce manual effort and support costs for this application?
questions.why: Automation reduces labor costs, improves consistency, and allows staff to focus on higher-value activities.

questions.text: What percentage of support effort is reactive (firefighting) versus proactive (improvement) work?
questions.why: High reactive effort indicates stability problems and creates a vicious cycle that prevents strategic improvements.

questions.text: How do the application's resource utilization and efficiency metrics compare to benchmarks?
questions.why: Inefficient resource usage indicates optimization opportunities through performance tuning or architectural improvements.

questions.text: What cost reduction opportunities would modernization or platform consolidation enable?
questions.why: Modernization can reduce costs through more efficient technologies, simplified architectures, and reduced maintenance overhead.

dimensions.name: 4. Modernization Potential
dimensions.description: Assesses the feasibility and business case for modernizing the application.

aspects.name: 4.1. Technical Feasibility
aspects.rationale: Technical constraints and complexities determine modernization feasibility and approach.

questions.text: How complex would it be to decouple and modernize components of this application incrementally?
questions.why: Incremental modernization reduces risk and allows value delivery before completing the full modernization effort.

questions.text: What are the technical risks and challenges associated with modernizing this application?
questions.why: Understanding technical risks helps plan mitigation strategies and set realistic expectations for modernization outcomes.

questions.text: How suitable is the application's architecture for cloud-native deployment models?
questions.why: Cloud compatibility influences modernization approach, costs, and the benefits achievable through modernization.

questions.text: What is the quality and completeness of documentation needed to support modernization?
questions.why: Poor documentation increases modernization risk and may require reverse engineering, adding time and cost to the effort.

questions.text: How accessible is the application's data for migration to modern platforms or architectures?
questions.why: Data migration complexity often determines modernization feasibility and may drive the technical approach.

aspects.name: 4.2. Business Case & Value
aspects.rationale: Modernization must deliver clear business value to justify the investment and disruption.

questions.text: What specific business benefits would modernization deliver (cost reduction, revenue growth, risk reduction)?
questions.why: Clear articulation of benefits is essential for building a compelling business case and securing modernization funding.

questions.text: What is the estimated return on investment (ROI) and payback period for modernizing this application?
questions.why: Financial metrics help prioritize modernization initiatives and ensure they deliver acceptable returns on investment.

questions.text: How would modernization enable new business capabilities or strategic initiatives?
questions.why: Modernization should enable business transformation, not just technical improvement, to maximize value delivery.

questions.text: What is the opportunity cost of not modernizing this application?
questions.why: Understanding the cost of inaction helps justify modernization investments by quantifying the risks of maintaining the status quo.

questions.text: How strong is executive sponsorship and business support for modernizing this application?
questions.why: Strong sponsorship is critical for modernization success, as these initiatives often face organizational resistance and competing priorities.
